properties.Name: Kunming
properties.description:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kunming

Known in China as the "City of Eternal Spring" (春城, Chūnchéng), Kunming lies at an almost-tropical latitude but its 2000 m (6600 ft) altitude gives it a very temperate climate.

properties.Name: Minfeng-Niya
properties.description:
The location of this site was taken from Aurel Stein's expedition maps who calls it Mingfen, today its Niya. One of the lost towns on the southern caravan route.
http://dsr.nii.ac.jp/toyobunko/T-VIII-5-A-a-3/V-4/map/

properties.Name: Ruins of Niya
properties.description:
Discovered by Aurel Stein the area around Niya has become a favorite excavation site of the Chinese Academy. 8 geaves with northern European "mummies" (1600 BG) have been found here.
The location of this site was taken from Aurel Stein's expedition maps.
http://dsr.nii.ac.jp/toyobunko/T-VIII-5-A-a-3/V-4/map/

properties.Name: Minle - Putuang cave monastery
properties.description:
Matii Si or Putuang cave monastery. The temple was established during the Western Jing (317-42). There are about 70 caves with frescoes of the Northern Wei period (386-534) which makes this complex of prime historical importance.
For an elaborate overlay of the Silk Roads download from the post.

properties.Name: Kumtura
properties.description:
From Le Coq's journals (1913-14): see my post for Kizil.
In Komtura Hinyana and Mahayana communities coexisted in the 6th-7th cent AD, ("Western School", i.e., Indian and Iranian influences).

properties.Name: Kucha
properties.description: In the 5th - 9th cent AD Khucha was a Buddhist kingdom of red-haired, blue-eyed princes. Recovered manuscripts show that they spoke a Western European language ("centum", close to the Germanic languages) - not an Indo-Iranian ("hatem") dialect. Their language is called Tokharian, after a mythical tribe Herodot mentions. This seems to indicate that they migrated here in more recent times than the Indo-Iranian-European Migrations. Our understanding is incomplete - but look at their red-blond hair and possibly blue eyes in the caves of Kizil.

properties.Name: Korla
properties.In case you are wondering what Far Weste: Photos from a NJ kid lost in  Korla, the Albuquerque of China anno 2005

properties.Name: Khocho
properties.description: Khocho (Chotscho, Gaochang) was a cosmopolitan city where in the 6th - 9th cent. people on the Silk Road met: The population was Mahayana Buddhist, the Kings Manicheans and Nestorians Christians from Syria also lived there.(Djinghis Khan was a baptized Nestorian Christian!!), and  after the 9th century (Tang) Chinese.

properties.Name: Urumqi
properties.description: means beautiful pasture in Mongol, is the capital city as well as the transport hub and economy center of the Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region

properties.Name: Loulan
properties.description: City in the Lobnor depression which flourished during the earlier centuries of the Silk Road.  -  New excavation here unearthed graves holding blond Western Europeans (8-7th cent. BC) - "The Mummies of Urumchi".

properties.Name: Charchen
properties.description: Recently near here shaft graves yielded several mummified "Western European Giants" from around 2000 BC  - fully dressed in knitted woolen garments: a man, three women, and a baby buried togethernear Charchen. They are now in the Ürümchi Museum - "the Mummies of Urumchi". See  http://library.thinkquest.org/J003409/china.htm  The location of this site was taken from Aurel Stein's expedition maps. http://dsr.nii.ac.jp/toyobunko/T-VIII-5-A-a-3/V-4/map/

properties.Name: Kashgar
properties.description:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kashgar
An important trade and cultural centre of Xinjiang as well as the Silk Road for more than two millennia. There is the largest bazaar in Asia with daily traffic of more than 100,000

properties.Name: Pendjikent
properties.description:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panjakent
The origin of Zoastrianism. It is a large tell with unexcavated ruins of the city.
Needs more investigation.

properties.Name: Alexandria Eschate
properties.description:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexandria_Eschate
Alexandria Eschate was founded by Alexander the Great in 329 BC as his most advanced base in trhe Fergana Valley. Chinese historical records of the Han Dynasty describe the embassy of Zhang Qian to Alexandria Eschate around 130 BC. He encounteredt the Dayuan there, probably the last descendants of Alexander's Greeks. If so, this was the the first major interaction between an urbanized Indo-European culture and the Chinese civilization, which led to the opening up the Silk Road from the 1st century BC.
For an elaborate overlay of the Silk Roads download the post.

properties.Name: Dura-Europos
properties.description:
Dura-Europo was founded in 303 BC by the Seleucids on the east-west trade route. The new city, commemorating the birthplace of Alexander's successor Seleucus I Nicator. It was captured by the Romans in 165 AD and abandoned after a Sassanian siege in 256-257AD. It was covered by sand and mud and disappeared from sight.
For an elaborate overlay of the Silk Roads go to the post.

properties.Name: Merv
properties.description:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Merv
The ruins of Merv are an assembly of several walled cities very close to each other. - Cities in Central Asia (e.g. Marakanda-Samarkand) were never rebuilt on the same site so that they consist of a number of distinct, walled compounds each with its own name and from a different period. - Merv goes back to before the 5th cent BC. It enjoyed its historical apogee between the 6th and 12th cent. During this period Merv was home to a wide range of different religions beside the official Zoroastrianism of the Sassanids, including Buddhists, Manichaeans, and Nestorian Christians. During the 5th century AD, Merv was the seat of an archbishop of the Nestorian Church. It was a major city on the Silk Road. From 1145 to 1153 Merv had a population of 200,000. In 1221 Merv was destroyed by the son of Genghis Khan. It was rebuilt on an adjecent site. Merv was incorporated into Timur Tamelane's empire (1380), but it never recovered its former preeminance. Under the name of Bairam-Ali it lasted as an Uzbek city into the 18th century, when it was razed by an army from Bukhara for the last time.
A British-Turkmen team is presently performing extended archeological excavations there>
http://www.ucl.ac.uk/merv/
For an elaborate overlay of the Silk Roads go to the post.

properties.Name: Balkh Alexandria Oxiana
properties.description:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Balkh

Bactra or Balkh was one of the most romanticized but elusive towns on the Silk Road. Here the marriage of Alexander and Roxane took place in 327 BC.
In 2004 Alfred Foucher uncovered an accumulation of architectural blocks from demolished Greek buildings. 7 meters under the ramparts of the Kushan city, appeared an enclosure wall doubtlessly from the Greek period,with a stupa established by King Mega Soter (Vima Takto), in the middle of the 1st century BC. It is the oldest Bactrian Buddhist monument.

properties.Name: Wakhan
properties.description: Valley along which the Silk Road led.  Marco Polo traveled through it. During Winter the caravans moved down the frozen Wakhan River, a dangerous but much more convenient route than the mountain passes.

properties.Name: Tashkurgan
properties.description: Town where the the two Silk Roads met and the difficult passes of the Pamirs began. Known as the Stone City to Greek and Roman historians.

properties.Name: Qipan-Cipan
properties.description: Qipan-Cipan. A cave complex on the Southern Taklamakan Route I knew nothing about. Location and name from a new tourist guide in Chinese.

properties.Name: Hotan
properties.description:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hotan
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kingdom_of_Khotan
In the 5th-8th cent AD Khotan had a large thriving community of Buddhist monks, described by several Chinese travelers (e.g., Fa Xien) on their way to India.
The location of this site was taken from Aurel Stein's expedition maps.
http://dsr.nii.ac.jp/toyobunko/T-VIII-5-A-a-3/V-4/map/

properties.Name: Dorah Pass
properties.description:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dorah_Pass
Note, the area Northeast and Southwest from here is Hundu Kush Mountain Range

properties.Name: Takht-i-Bahai - Buddhist Monastery
properties.description:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Takht-i-Bahi

Large ruins of a Buddhist monastery and academy are found in a mountain valley (1st-6th cent AD). Many of the celebrated Greco-Gandharan Buddhist sculptures in Western museums come from here. A few are still in loco. The monastery is relatively well preseved.

properties.Name: Taxila - Greco-Buddhist Site
properties.Taxila lay at the crossroads of three ma: the royal highway from Pāliputra; the north-western route through Bactria, Kāpiśa, and Pukalāvatī (Peshawar); and the route from Kashmir and Central Asia, via Śrinigar, Mānsehrā, and the Haripur valley across the Khunjerab pass to Kashgar on the Silk Road

properties.Name: Fondukistan - Buddhist monastery
properties.Photo from: Madelleine Hallade, "Indien, Gandhara, Begegnung zwischen Orient and Okzident", Pawlak Verlag, Herrsching, 1975)

properties.Name: Basara
properties.description:
https://www.reddit.com/r/history/comments/nmimdm/why_didnt_the_ottoman_empire_stop_portuguese/

The Ottoman navy was strong, but it was based in the Mediterranean, where most Ottoman interests, and infrastructure were located. In the Indian Ocean, it was limited to the port of Basra.

In general, naval infrastructure in the Indian Ocean was lacking. The Ottomans and Portuguese appeared to have been the only professional naval forces around. The Mameluke Sultanate, which controlled the Red Sea, apparently had to order pre-assembled galleys and carracks from Venice to participate in the Battle of Diu. Shipbuilding is knowledge-intensive and easily bottlenecked industry, and the lack of warship-building tradition in the Indian Ocean meant that the Ottomans were as constrained as the Portuguese there.

In the end, the two powers came to an agreement over which ports each controlled. The Ottomans retained Basra, which seemed to satisfy them. It has to be noted that during this timeframe, (1500-1550), the Ottoman Empire was involved in several large land wars. They conquered the Mameluke Sultanate, Hungary, and defeated Safavid Persia. These commitments likely limited their investment into the Indian Ocean Fleet.

Finally, there was Venice's involvement. The Ottoman government's revenue was mainly tax-based, the income from trade tariffs was relatively minor and it did not "sell" trade rights to the Far East like the Portuguese. So their losses from Portuguese expansion were not much in monetary terms. For the Venetians however, the diversion of trade from the Indian Ocean had much more impact. They had a big hand in anti-Portuguese activities, like the preassembled galleys I mentioned, as well as negotiating a return to overland routes in Central Asia. They were decently successful, as their spice imports through Mediterranean ports had returned to acceptable levels by the 1550s.

As always, war is politics by other means.
